interlinear-text.item: ELA On the Wakhis in China

phrase.item: My name is Shamsbek.
How old are you?
I am 60 years old.
(ʃad for ʃast?)
I wasn't born here, I was born in Pakistan.
I was born there. I was very little when my father brought me here. We lived in 'Davdor' then from there [moved] to 'Garmi' and then [came] here.
We don't have our own kids but we raised a daughter,
my cousin's daughter.
She married and is living down [in the village].
I consider all my brother's kids to be my own kids.
So they are like my children.
We, wife and husband, are cousins.
My father-in-law had only one daughter and my father wanted me to marry her.
Originally, the Wakhis came from Pakistan. The Tashkurgan Wakhis migrated from Pakistan.
The elders, they settled here.
They are Chinese citizens. They are not immigrants or travelers.
It's been more than a hundred years since they moved here.
So they moved here quite a long time ago.
No, there isn't anyone who moved here from Tajikistan.
Nobody is from Tajikistan.
They have probably returned.
We were very little when we came here,
and we grew up here.
While we grew up, we worked as shepherds for people.
[During] that time life was like that.
There weren't corporations like [there are] now.
Everyone worked for themselves. Rich people would mistreat poor people.
The Communist Party brought freedom to this place. Poor people's value increased.
After that the time of the corporations came.
After the corporations, the Communist time came.
We all worked and after that we worked in cooperatives, then it finished. Deng Xiaoping set in throne, and Chairman Mao died.
He had destroyed all the
fields and took everything away [?] Then we joined the Party, and the Party was ruling. And with the Communist Party in charge, we didn't have any difficulties, and we are satisfied.
[We're] very good,
we don't have any problems.
The goverment is taking care of us, because we don't have skills.
So they built us a house. They check on us quite often. They come and ask if everything is ok.
Even when we say that we don't have [any] problems, they still help us.
The Wakhi people came a long time ago, during the Qing [Dynasty] time,
our grandfathers said.
Then our people migrated later.
These people moved from Pakistan. When they fell on hard times, they ran away to [China].
People were taken into the army by force by the Afghans.
[Someone] would die there [in the army] and [Afghans] would come destroy the house, saying that the person had run away.
My grandfathers used to tell me these stories.
Then the people from there [moved here]. When a male was born, an Afghan would register him in a notebook with all [his] information. When he turned 18 they would come and take him away
to serve in the army.
He would go there and drink the dirty water and suffer and eventually would die.
[Then the Afghans] would assume the person ran away and would come to his house and take everything from the household. They would repeat this every year.
All these stories were told to us by our grandfathers.
So, they [the Wakhis] moved here and settled.
First they stayed in 'Athord' village.
Then they moved to 'Garmi' village,
then to 'Qarasi', which you probably passed on the way. Our people live over there also,
but mainly [our] people are based in 'Garmi'.
My grandfather had two brothers [sons], one is based in 'Thawthor' and the other in 'Garmi'.
The younger brother lived in 'Thawthor' and the elder brother was in 'Garmi'.
So they were two sons,
but one died,
the younger one.
The elder brother was my father.
My father also died at a young age.
His brain was bleeding, that's why.
My grandfather, then my father died.
